p: Of note, in addition to the above exogenous retroviruses, the DNA of all vertebrate contains endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), which are ancient traces of past infections found as viral footprints in the genome of the various species. The ones found in humans, the human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs), represent as approximately 8% of the human genome and have been recently classified into 39 main groups [ 3]. These viral footprints are virus-associated sequences that closely resemble present-day retroviral (e.g., HIV) elements, including the 5’ and 3’ long terminal repeats (LTR), and the coding genes gag, pro-pol, and env [ 4]. However, their long-time persistence in the host genome has led to the accumulation of mutations as well as insertions and deletions, which have generally affected their capacity to produce infectious virions [ 5].
